Thanks, Scott. I'm pretty sure I have my filters right; I've done 
enough jpcoverage before.
I'll look into useing ant's jpcoverage task.
MT

--- In junit@y..., "Scott Stirling" <scottstirling@r...> wrote:
> I always go the other way -- use Ant's jpcoverage to run JProbe
> Coverage.  Easier to automate most of the steps (run x n, merge,
> report).
> 
> Last time I got 0% coverage was because I accidentally had a * 
exclusion
> filter.  Check your filters in the Coverage launchpad.
> 
> Another benefit to Ant's jpcoverage is that the exclusion/inclusion
> mechanism is a little more "in your face."  And if you use 
jpcovreport,
> you get a much nicer looking report than the JProbe HTML report.
> 
> Scott Stirling
> 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: majortaylor [mailto:majortaylor@y...] 
> > 
> > Hi,
> > I'm trying to get some code coverage for my junit tests. I'm 
using 
> > JProbe Coverage from Sitraka software to get the code coverage 
> > information.
> > JPCoverage calls ant which in turn runs my unit tests. I've been 
> > careful to set "fork="no" in my junit ant task so that my tests 
run 
> > in the same jvm as ant.
> > Despite this, and despite the fact that it's clear my tests are 
> > executing, jpcoverage is still reporting 0% coverage of my 
> > code. Does anybody have any experience with this? I'm 
> > wondering what I 
> > could be doing wrong.
> > I realize that there's also a jpcoverage ant task which would 
then 
> > run JProbe inside my ant project (rather than vice versa); would 
this 
> > be a superior approach? I suspect I would have the same problem.
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > MT
